title: Abū Madyan
source_editors: Kate Fleet, Gudrun Krämer, Denis Matringe, John Nawas, and Devin J. Stewart
content: Abū Madyan Shuʿayb (d. 589/1193 or 594/1198, near Tlemcen) was a Ṣūfī from the region of Seville, who settled in Fez at the end of the era of the Almoravids (r. 454–541/1062–1147). He still influences the western Muslim world, with his synthesis of Maghribī and Andalusian spirituality with eastern Ṣūfism. We will discuss his life, his work and teaching, and his path, and will conclude with discussions of his influence in architecture and his spiritual descendants.
1. The life of Abū Madyan Shuʿayb

Strangely, given his importance as “master of the masters of the Maghrib” in his day, there is no monograph on Abū Madyan that brings together all the biographical and hagiographical data about him, his teachings, and an exhaustive list of his many disciples. The first sources that mention him were based on piecemeal information that would be taken up by subsequent authors and to which occasional, sometimes legendary, elements were added. The first source is al-Mustafād , a collection of records of the saints of Fez who were contemporaries of the Moroccan Ṣūfī, traditionist, and hagiographer al-Tamīmī (d. c.603/1206–7), who was born in Fez and who died there upon his return from a sojourn in the East. He spent time with Abū Madyan during the latter’s stay in Fez and informs us of his masters and some of his companions and disciples. The second source is the Tashawwuf by Yūsuf b. Yaḥyā al-Tādilī Ibn al-Zayyāt (d. 627 or 628/1230 or 1231). This work deals mainly with the saints of Marrakech and its surroundings but also provides valuable information about Abū Madyan, his masters, and his disciples, some of whom Ibn al-Zayyāt knew personally.

According to two disciples of Abū Madyan, Ibn al-Zayyāt transmits a double autobiographical account of his early period as shaykh. Abū Madyan was born in Ḥiṣn Qaṭyāna (Cantillana), some thirty kilometres northwest of Seville, on the right bank of the Guadalquivir, into a family descended from the Anṣār of Medina, if one is to believe the nisba accorded him by al-Tādilī. According to Ibn al-Abbār (d. 658/1260)—the Andalusian poet, diplomat, theologian, and scholar from Valencia—and several others, however, he was born in Mantūjab, a fortified village near Seville (Ibn al-Abbār, 4:137). Orphaned at a young age, he herded the livestock of his brothers. Eager to learn the Qurʾān by heart and to be instructed in Islam, he tried to escape, against the will of one of his brothers, who let him go, having received a miraculous sign. Arriving at the coast, he met a mysterious person who sent him back to Seville, but he soon crossed the Mediterranean, went to Tangier and then Sabta (Ceuta), worked for a time as a fisherman, and then went to Marrakech, where he and other Andalusians enlisted in the army. He was advised to go to Fez, if his desire was to study.

Al-Tamīmī informs us that Abū Madyan first resided in the mosque of the Andalusian quarter, where he led the life of an ascetic in retreat and attended the circles of jurists and preachers (mudhakkirūn) , until he met Abū l-Ḥasan ʿAlī Ibn Ḥirzihim (d. 559/1164), whose words touched his heart and who initiated him into the reading of the Riʿāya li-ḥuqūq Allāh (“The observance of God’s rights”) by al-Muḥasibī (d. 243/857) and the Iḥyāʾ ʿulūm al-dīn (“The revival of the religious sciences”) by al-Ghazālī (d. 505/1111). Ibn Ḥirzihim had received the work of al-Ghazālī through his two masters—his uncle Abū Muḥammad Ṣāliḥ b. Ḥirzihim and the qāḍī Abū Bakr b. al-ʿArabī (d. 543/1148). According to the Tashawwuf (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 228, no. 81), he also studied the ḥadīth collection by al-Tirmidhī (d. 279/892) with the Andalusian Abū l-Ḥasan ʿAlī b. Khalaf Ibn Ghālib (d. 568/1172–3), a disciple of Ibn al-ʿArīf (d. 536/1141–2).

Ibn Ḥirzihim and Ibn Ghālib belonged to the spiritual circles of Fez, but Abū Madyan still considered his two masters in Ṣūfism to be Abū l-Ḥasan al-Salāwī and Abū ʿAbdallāh al-Daqqāq. Of the former we know nothing, but there are a few anecdotes about the latter that illustrate nonconformist behaviour, at the same time concealing and confirming his affiliation to the hierarchy of the saints. Originally from Sijilmāsa, he frequently visited Fez, where he died at an unknown date (al-Tamīmī, 2:186–9; Ibn al-Zayyāt, 156–7, no. 41; Ibn ʿArabī, al-Futūhāt , 1:244, 2:12, 4:503; al-Kattānī, Salwat al-anfās , no. 994, 3:127–9 and 1:417; Bel).

According to al-Tamīmī (2:42), Abū Madyan performed his peregrinations (siyāḥa) at first without carrying anything with him, neither stick nor bowl. To those who were surprised by this, he replied, “Remembrance (dhikr) is my bowl and the realisation of divine unity (tawḥīd) is my stick.” He tells us that, whenever he learned a verse from the Qurʾān or a ḥadīth by heart, he would leave Fez to isolate himself in the ruins of a building, in order to implement what he had learned from them. He adds that the dogs on the road would welcome him and that a gazelle would come to him. One day, on his way back to Fez, the dogs began to bark at him and the gazelle fled from him, and he realised that, despite his efforts, he still had some money on him. He regained familiarity with the animals only after giving the money to the person for whom it was intended (cf. Ibn al-Zayyāt, 322). This story, which has been repeated by several authors, illustrates the ideal of detachment that Abū Madyan preached and practised. Later, in Fez, when al-Tamīmī asked him to read the Risāla of al-Qushayrī (d. 465/1072–3), the Ṣūfī master of of Nīshāpūr, under his supervision, he answered that it would be sufficient for him to ponder just one ḥadīth , “The love for this world is the source of all sin” (al-Tamīmī, 2:42).

Abū Madyan, trained in the exoteric and Ṣūfī sciences in Fez, apparently achieved the spiritual mastery that he exercised there only after Abū Yaʿzā Yallanūr (d. 572/1177, at the age of more than one hundred) completed his spiritual education by testing him and sending him back to educate disciples and future masters. This Berber saint and illiterate was the disciple of Abū Shuʿayb al-Ṣanhājī (d. 561/1166), the patron saint of the Moroccan city Azammūr, whose master was initiated in Egypt into a spiritual path (not formally a ṭarīqa ) that goes back to Abū l-Ḥusayn al-Nūrī (d. 295/908), companion of al-Junayd (d. 298/910), the prominent Ṣūfī mystic of Baghdad (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 187–92, no. 62; Cornell, Realm , 57–62).

His reputation for holiness attracted many visitors, including several ʿulamāʾ , to his hermitage of Tāghiyā, in Irrūgān in the Middle Atlas. His hagiographers depict Abū Yaʿzā as practising rigorous asceticism, serving others, feeding guests, performing many miracles, penetrating the hidden intentions and depravities of his visitors, and demonstrating, by his holiness, the power and generosity of God (al-Tamīmī, 2:28–40, no. 2; Ibn al-Zayyāt, 213–22, no. 77; al-ʿAzafī; Aḥmad al-Ṣawmaʿī; Lévi-Provençal, Abū Yaʿazzā, EI2 ; Cornell, Realm , 68–79).

According to his autobiographical record in the Tashawwuf , Abū Madyan, after completing his training in Fez, went with a group to visit Abū Yaʿzā. The latter received the visitors but turned away from Abū Madyan. He brought them their meal but ushered Abū Madyan away from it; this continued for three days. Abū Madyan waited patiently; as a sign of humility, he rubbed his face on the ground on the spot where the master had been sitting and lost his sight. The next day, Abū Yaʿzā summoned him, returned his sight by running his hand over his face, and predicted a great future for him. He then allowed him to leave, first predicting the miraculous signs that he would encounter on his way. The rest of the record shows that Abū Madyan visited Abū Yaʿzā repeatedly. Al-Tamīmī shows Abū Madyan in Fez surrounded by companions and disciples. As the author of the Mustafād returned from his eastern sojourn in 576/1180 (1:98), he must have been visiting with Abū Madyan for several years before that date. Had Abū Madyan not left Fez only after the death of Abū Yaʿzā in 572/1177 to take up residence in Bijāya (Béjaïa, Bougie)? Did he do this on the advice of his master, as later authors suggest?

At this stage of Abū Madyan’s life, the issue of a journey to the East comes into question. From the ninth/fifteenth century on, authors assert that, on leaving Abū Yaʿzā, he expressed to him his intention to perform the pilgrimage. On ʿArafat (near Mecca), he presumably met ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Jīlānī (a Ḥanbalī scholar active in Baghdad, who, after his death in 561/1166, became the namesake and patron of the widespread Qādiriyya Ṣūfī order) and received from him the khirqa (a garment, hence support for transmission of initiation or spiritual influence). The fact, however, that no source, not even Ibn Qunfūdh (d. 810/1407–8), the great scholar from Constantine, mentions it has led many researchers to doubt that this journey and meeting actually occurred (al-ʿĀmirī, al-Taṣawwuf , 122; Cornell, Realm , 152; ʿAbd al-Salām Gharmīnī, 327–8). Ibn Qunfūdh reports only on his departure for the East (thumma inṣarafa musharriq) and his numerous travels to Ifrīqiya (the mediaeval eastern Maghrib) before settling in Bijāya ( Uns al-faqīr , 16). Had Abū Madyan performed the ḥajj , al-Tamīmī, who lived in the East, would certainly have mentioned it. Had he affiliated himself with al-Jīlānī, the Egyptian al-Shaṭṭanawfī (d. 713/1313) would have reported it, as the latter tried incessantly to demonstrate every saint’s recognition of ʿAbd al-Qādir’s authority, who had declared, “My foot rests on the neck of all saints” and who mentions Abū Madyan among those who acknowledged al-Jīlānī’s superiority from afar, through unveiling ( Bahjat , 15; included by al-Yāfiʿī, d. 768/1367, in Nashr , 289–90).

It is telling that one of the first to mention the pilgrimage of Abū Madyan and his investiture with the khirqa by al-Jīlānī was Ibn Ṣaʿd al-Tilimsānī (d. 901/1496), the Tlemcen scholar and hagiographer, in his al-Najm al-thāqib (320), included by Ibn Maryam in al-Bustān (110, trans. Provenzali, 105). From the ninth/fifteenth century on, the Qādiriyya spread in the Muslim world and was introduced into the Maghrib. Perhaps there was a more subtle aspect to the relationship between ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Jīlānī and Abū Madyan, or perhaps there was a confusion of identity between al-Jīlānī and the Iraqi Aḥmad al-Rifāʿī (d. 578/1182), founder of the Rifāʿī Ṣūfī order, as suggested by the work of ʿAbd al-Ḥaqq al-Bādisī (fl. 711/1311–2) on the saints of the Moroccan Rif. Bādisī mentions a shaykh of this region who would have been the disciple of al-Rifāʿī and says that the latter was the master of Baghdad at the time of Abū Madyan, hence the possible confusion with al-Jīlānī. He then says that al-Rifāʿī and Abū Madyan met at ʿArafat, that the latter dressed the former in a crimson garment (qirmīziyya) and that the former dressed the latter in a camlet mantle (barrakīn , prob. for barrakān). The author adds, “Some say that they did not meet physically, but in spirit” (al-Bādisī, 64). A verse by the Egyptian Ṣūfī poet al-Būṣīrī (d. 696/1297) about Abū Madyan and his disciples confirms this fraternal bond between the two saints (al-Mājirī, 161).

The famous Moroccan traveller Ibn Baṭṭūṭa (d. 779/1377) relates the following anecdote on the occasion of his visit to the shrine of Shaykh Arslān (d. c. 550–5/1155–60) in Damascus. Abū Madyan and Aḥmad al-Rifāʿī were connected by a spiritual bond of fraternity. One year, the latter set aside rations of dates for his brother and then went on pilgrimage, where he met Abū Madyan at ʿArafat. Arslān, who is presented as a servant of al-Rifāʿī, set out to look for the rations in the form of an ashen-white falcon (bāz ashhab) , an epithet generally accorded ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Jīlānī (Ibn Baṭṭūṭa, 1:223–5). Ibn Ṣaʿd al-Tilimsānī (138) also reports a miraculous exchange of food between Abū Madyan and al-Rifāʿī. These accounts express graphically the relations between the members of the hierarchy of saints and reflect the relations between the spiritual circles of the Muslim East and West between which Abū Madyan was one of the main intermediaries.

It is said that Abū Madyan moved to Bijāya after his long stay in Fez because he considered this city especially propitious in the search for a way to make a lawful living ( ṭalab al-ḥalāl ; Ibn Maryam, El-Boustane , 109), which points to the rigorous principles (waraʿ) that he upheld, according to Ibn ʿArabī (d. 638/1240–1), the great spiritual master of Andalusian origin ( al-Futūḥāt , 1:244, chap. 43; Mawāqiʿ al-nujūm , 114). Moreover, the city of Bijāya, a prosperous Mediterranean seaport inhabited by Andalusians, which was conquered by the Almohads in 547/1152, was a favoured venue for meetings and exchanges between various groups of western and eastern Muslims. The choice of Bijāya contributed to the dissemination of the teachings of Abū Madyan. It is telling that al-Ghubrīnī (d. 714/1314), a jurist, qāḍī , and biographer from Bijāya, opens his ʿUnwān al-dirāya with an account of Abū Madyan, followed by accounts of Ḥasan al-Masīlī (d. c. 580/1184) and ʿAbd al-Ḥaqq al-Ishbīlī (d. 581/1185)—the first originating from the inner central Maghrib, the second from al-Andalus, and both renowned for their knowledge and piety. In Bijāya, Abū Madyan also met with Abū Zakariyyā Yaḥyā al-Zawāwī (d. 611/1214), well-known for his rigour and righteousness (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 428), whose grave became the site of pious visits. It is in this environment that Abū Madyan taught and exercised his spiritual authority over the many disciples attracted by his saintly aura. There are anecdotes about fuqahāʾ (jurisconsults, Ar. pl. of faqīh ) subjecting him to tests in which he miraculously succeeds. Was it because of their envy, as al-Ghubrīnī claims, that Abū Madyan was reported to the Almohad caliph Abū Yūsuf Yaʿqūb al-Manṣūr (r. 580–95/1184–99), who summoned him to Marrakech, despite his old age? Abū Madyan tells his saddened disciples that God wants to lead him to where he is to finish his days and that neither will he see the powerful men of the state nor will they see him. He died in the vicinity of Tlemcen, saying “Allāh, Allāh” (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 323; Ibn Qunfūdh, Uns al-faqīr , 103), “Allāh al-Ḥayy” (God, the living). According to Ibn Qunfūdh (102–3), on approaching the town of al-ʿUbbād he asked its name and said malīḥ li-l-ruqād (“that is a pleasant place to rest!”), or, as reported later, niʿma l-ruqād (“what an excellent place to rest!”). This tradition contradicts another, also related by Ibn Qunfūdh, in which Abū Madyan dies on the bank of the river Isser, in present-day western Algeria. The village of ʿAïn Tekbalet, which lies some thirty kilometres north of Tlemcen, on the way to ʿAïn Temouchent, still has a small qubba (dome) near the mosque, built on the site of his death. He was buried in al-ʿUbbād, a place of retreat for pious persons southeast of Tlemcen, next to ʿAbd al-Salām al-Tūnisī (d. at the beginning of the reign of the Almohad caliph ʿAbd al-Muʾmin, or about 524/1130, according to Bargès, Tlemcen , 273–4; about this shaykh , see Ibn al-Zayyāt, 123–4; Ibn Qunfūdh, 106–8; Ibn Maryam, El-Boustane , 118 and n. 478; and Addas, Ibn ʿArabī , 39–41). According to Ibn Qunfūdh (104), the funeral of Abū Madyan was commemorated across the entire Maghrib. It left such an impression that it caused the conversion to the spiritual path of a certain ʿUmar al-Ḥabbāk (d. 613/1216), who was therefore considered a disciple of Abū Madyan (Ṣafī al-Dīn, § 64–64b; Ibn Maryam, El-Boustane , n. 440).

There is another explanation for al-Manṣūr’s summoning of Abū Madyan. The caliph, feeling remorse at the end of his life for the murder of his brother, wants to abdicate the throne and consecrate himself to God. He is advised to turn to Abū Madyan. Arriving near Tlemcen, the latter felt his death approaching and sent a message to the sultan that he would find spiritual health in the person of Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Mariyī. Al-Manṣūr became his disciple, renounced the world, and attained a certain level of sanctity. This version is presented by the Egyptian Ṣafī al-Dīn Ibn Abī l-Manṣūr (d. 682/1283), who, in his youth, knew Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Mariyī, disciple of Abū Madyan, nicknamed al-Qanjarāy (d. 627/1230) after the name of his native village in Andalusia (Ṣafī al-Dīn, § 82–85b). ʿAbd al-Wāḥid al-Marrakushī, the historian of the Almohads who wrote in 621/1224, confirms the relation between this person and al-Manṣūr ( al-Muʿjib , 417) (for the remorse of the latter and his retreat from power in favour of his son, see M. Shatzmiller, al-Muwaḥḥidūn, EI2 ). According to most authors, Abū Madyan died in 594/1198, but al-Ghubrīnī places his death in 590/1194 (ʿUnwān , 10; see also al-Yāfiʿī, Mirʾāt al-janān) and Ibn ʿArabī, alluding to Abū Madyan without naming him, speaks of a “pole who passed away” (daraja) in 589/1193 (al-Futūḥāt) , 4:195, title of chap. 556; date accepted by Ibn al-ʿImād). If daraja here means “dying,” then Ṣafī al-Dīn’s version cannot be correct, because al-Manṣūr could not have renounced power before his victory over Alfonso VIII of Castile at Alarcos in 591/1195, followed by a second expedition in Spain the following year. Ibn ʿArabī, who considered Abū Madyan his master without ever having met him physically, was in Tlemcen and Tunis in 590/1194, in the company of ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz al-Mahdawī, a disciple of Abū Madyan. Addas contends that Ibn ʿArabī must therefore have stopped in Bijāya to visit Abū Madyan, had the latter still been alive. He also mentions his visit to the tomb of Abū Madyan but without providing a date (Ibn ʿArabī, Muḥāḍarat , 2:115; Addas, Abu Madyan, 175–6). Ibn ʿArabī does not leave the Maghrib until 598/1202. The date of death of Abū Madyan therefore remains an open question.
2. Teachings

Abū Madyan is one of those masters whose work consists above all in the training of his disciples through teaching and the setting of an example. Asked for final advice when he was about to die, he said, “Glory be to God: was my entire life with you not advice (or a testament, waṣiyya )?” (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 323). The teachings that he provided to his disciples did not consist only of the texts that he had received from his masters, mainly the Risāla fī l-taṣawwuf (“Treatise on Ṣūfism”) by al-Qushayrī and the Iḥyāʾ ʿulūm al-Dīn (“The revitalization of religious disciplines”) by al-Ghazālī, the major religious scholar, mystic, theologian, and Ṣūfī born and raised in Khurāsān (d. 505/1111). The core of Abū Madyan’s teachings consists of short maxims and his answers to various questions. One of these, for example, first cited by al-Tamīmī and later by Ibn ʿArabī, defines the three stages of spiritual progress: “The sign of the sincerity of the aspiring person in his desire for God is his fleeing from (God’s) creatures (khalq); the sign of the sincerity of his fleeing is that he exists only for God; the sign that he exists only for God is his returning to (God’s) creatures” (al-Tamīmī, 44; Ibn ʿArabī, Futūḥāt , 1:251, 2:22). Al-Ghubrīnī was the first to publish a collection of these maxims, which differ considerably from those attributed to him by other authors ( ʿUnwān al-dirāya , 30–2, included in Ibn Qunfūdh, Uns al-faqīr , 18–9). This constitutes the core of a more comprehensive later collection entitled Uns al-waḥīd wa-nuzhat al-murīd (“Intimacy of the solitary and delight of the disciple”), edited and translated by Cornell ( The way , 116–49; see the manuscript references on p. 11, note 1). Khālid Zahrī has made a critical edition of it, published with Ibn ʿAṭāʾ Allāh’s ʿUnwān al-tawfīq (see below). There are, however, other collections, some of them partial, such as the account of al-Shaʿrānī (d. 973/1565, Ṭabaqāt , 133–4), that of ʿAbd al-Raʾūf al-Munāwī (d. 1031/1622; 2:242–3), or that of ʿAlī l-Bayyūmī (d. 1183/1769) in his commentary on Abū Madyan’s Ḥikam (aphorisms). On the other hand, the list of maxims in the commentary of Aḥmad b. ʿAllān al-Ṣiddīqī (d. 1033/1624), Sharḥ al-Ḥikam al-ghawthiyya , does correspond more or less closely to the one in the Uns al-waḥīd . This Ḥikam has also been commented on by Aḥmad b. ʿAbd al-Qādir, also known as Bāʿashan(?), in al-Bayān wa-l-mazīd al-mushtamil ʿalā maʿānī al-tanzīh wa-ḥaqāʾiq al-tawḥīd (“The clarification and addition that comprises the meanings of transcendence and the realities of divine unity,” Cairo 1300/1883, repr. Beirut 2005). Contrary to this, Aḥmad Ibn ʿAlīwa (d. 1934), the Ṣūfī master and poet from Mostaganem, chose to arrange the maxims by theme (al-Mawādd al-ghaythiyya al-nāshiʾa ʿan al-Ḥikam al-ghawthiyya). The text that is sometimes called the Latin translation of the Ḥikam—Abu Medini Mauri Fessani sententiae quaedam arabicae (trans. F. de Dombay, Vienna 1805)—is really nothing more than the Tuḥfat al-arīb wa-nuzhat al-labīb , a collection of proverbs by a certain Abū Madyan b. Muḥammād al-Fāsī (d. 1181/1768). Also, a short text on religious doctrine (al-ʿAqīda al-mubāraka) and a treatise on Ṣūfism entitled Bidāyat al-murīd (“The first steps of the disciple”; cf. Cornell, The way , 48–53 and 54–115). This last text certainly contains phrases by Abū Madyan, but it also quotes from other sources, among them the Qawāʿid al-ṣūfiyya (“The rules of the Ṣūfīs”) by the Egyptian Ṣūfī master Muḥammad b. ʿUmar al-Ghamrī (d. 849/1445), so it is a late compilation. The Ifrīqī (Tunisian) hagiographer ʿAbd al-Wāḥid Ibn al-Ṭawwāḥ (d. after 718/1318) quotes, in the Sabk al-maqāl li-fakk al-ʿiqāl (“The melting of the discourse to untie the bonds”) (58–64), a few excerpts of a correspondence between Abū Madyan and his disciple ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz al-Mahdawī (d. 621/1224). Several poems also are attributed to Abū Madyan. The only one whose attribution is certain is the Rāʾiyya on the rules of adab of the Ṣūfī path ( Mā ladhdhat al-ʿaysh illā ṣuḥbat al-fuqarāʾ , “The sweetness of life lies only in the company of those who live in poverty striving for God”). Ibn ʿAṭāʾ Allāh al-Iskandarī (d. 709/1309–10), the third master of the Shadhiliyya, has written a commentary on it titled ʿUnwān al-tawfīq fī ādāb al-ṭarīq (the Shadhiliyya was founded by the Moroccan Abū l-Ḥasan al-Shādhilī, d. 656/1258, and is well established in North Africa and the central Middle East). The Dīwān of Abū Madyan was published by al-ʿArabī b. Muṣṭafā al-Shawwār (al-Tilimsānī) (Damascus 1938). Several recent works devoted to Abū Madyan contain selections of his poetry. For all the texts that have been attributed to him and their manuscripts, see, among others, Fārisī’s well documented Abū Madyan Shuʿayb . Karrūm (spelt Guerroum, which represents the dialect pronunciation) has shown that some of the poems in the Dīwān contain verses that are found also in the Majnūn wa-Laylā corpus and that one poem resembles one attributed to Yaḥyā Suhrawardī, father of the “Illuminationist” school of Ṣūfism (executed in Aleppo for political reasons in 587/1191). There is also some confusion between poetry attributed to Abū Madyan and that of the Andalusī Ṣūfī poet Abū l-Ḥasan al-Sushtarī (d. 668/1269–70). The latter is renowned, among the masters of Ṣūfism, for being the first to use zajal (pl. azjāl , a form of poetry using exclusively dialectal Arabic), just as Ibn ʿArabī was the first to use the muwashshaḥ (written in Andalusian Arabic or in Old Spanish). The few azjāl and muwashshaḥāt attributed to Abū Madyan and collected by Muḥammad Murābiṭ in 1271/1855 in his Jawāhir al-ḥisān (published 1974) reflect the poetic tradition of the city better than the work of its patron saint. Beyond the problems of attribution they raise, the poems of Abū Madyan, still recited in the zāwiya s (Ṣūfī lodges) in both West and East, have helped keep alive his memory and perpetuate his veneration.

An essential source on Abū Madyan is the work of Ibn ʿArabī. The latter did not meet Abū Madyan physically, but he was acquainted with some of his disciples and received from them anecdotes and sayings of the master. Addas has studied the relationship between Abū Madyan and Ibn ʿArabī, who considers himself his disciple (references to Abū Madyan in Ibn ʿArabī are to be found below, in the bibliography). For Ibn ʿArabī, Abū Madyan is the incarnation of him who has received true knowledge, inspired by God on the model of the Revelation, of which he said, “The one who seeks God (murīd) does not seek him truly, as long as he does not find everything that he seeks (yurīd) in the Qurʾan” ( al-Futūḥāt , 3:94, chap. 325). Abū Madyan achieved the holiness that perpetuates the foundational virtues, such as the rigorous principles (waraʿ) , but he was also the incarnation of the Prophetic model in returning to human beings after having attained God (see, above, his sentence on the three stages of spiritual progress). He stood at the acme of the hierarchy of the saints, which, according to the testimony of Ibn ʿArabī, he reached shortly before his death—hence his epithets Ghawth (“Rescue”) and Quṭb (“Supreme Pole”)—after being “the imām of the left,” the assistant of the Pole, who has authority over the tangible world (mulk) , whence his particular relation with sūra 67 of the Qurʾān, al-Mulk (“the Kingdom”). Concomitantly, he represents immersion in the divine Unity through invocation (dhikr) and the realisation (achievement) of absolute servitude. His few karāmāt (miracles) reported by Ibn ʿArabī and the first hagiographers are intended less to emphasise the miracles than to demonstrate his nearness to God and his clear-sightedness as a spiritual master (Addas, Abu Madyan and Ibn ʿArabī; ʿAbd al-Bāqī Miftaḥ, al-Imām Abū Madyan wa-l-Shaykh al-Akbar Muḥyī l-Dīn Ibn al-ʿArabī, in Hikmet, 82–119).

The teachings of Abū Madyan, as they have been transmitted by his first witnesses or transmitters, are expressed straightforwardly. There is, however, another form of expression of the master’s initiatory doctrine and metaphysics, one which his disciples received in visions. Abū Madyan would most often appear in their dreams and would be questioned by illustrious Ṣūfī figures such as the Persian ascetic mystic Abū Yazīd al-Bisṭāmī (d. 260/874 or 263/876–7), the traditionist, Shafiʿī jurist, and ascetic mystic Abū Ṭālib al-Makkī (d. 386/996), and al-Ghazālī. His answers were of great spiritual significance, expressed in an eloquent language that differs greatly from that of his other known expressions. One example is found in the Tashawwuf (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 325–6) and others in the Muḥāḍarat al-abrār by Ibn ʿArabī and in the Shihābmawʿiẓat ulī l-albāb (“The flame, an exhortation for those who have an intelligent heart”) attributed to Abū Aḥmad Jaʿfar Ibn Sīd Būna (see below) and written down by one of his disciples. This type of transmission transcends issues of authenticity and falls within the scope of the dissemination of the teachings of Abū Madyan by his disciples.
3. The path of Abū Madyan

The fame of Abū Madyan during his lifetime and after his death resulted both from his personality and his teachings, which synthesise several strands of spirituality, and from his many disciples, who extended his influence from al-Andalus to the Near East. He still remains the emblematic figure of spirituality in the Muslim West. He did not, strictly speaking, establish a “path” in the sense that the word ṭarīqa would later acquire. We do not generally speak of a Madyaniyya ṭarīqa , because Abū Madyan carried on the ancient method of initiatory transmission based on companionship (ṣuḥba) , and his disciples mostly followed this model. As we have seen, the spiritual model embodied by Abū Madyan, as among most of the Ṣūfī masters of the Maghrib, rests upon apprenticeship and respect for the law, the practice of virtues, detachment from the world, and an orientation totally towards God. As to collective practice, Abū Madyan held spiritual sessions (samāʿ) at his home (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 332). We also know that individual initiation among his disciples was based on spiritual retreat (khalwa). This was no more remarkable, in itself, than the miracles that have been attributed to him. The importance of Abū Madyan, along with his position in the hierarchy of sainthood, lies, however, in his powerful contribution to the merging, in the sixth/twelfth-century Almohad Maghrib, of Andalusian spirituality—especially that of the school of Almería—with the simple and ascetic lifestyle of the masters of the city and of the Moroccan countryside and the classical teachings of Ṣūfism, based in part on the Risāla of al-Qushayrī and the Iḥyāʾ of al-Ghazālī, which Abū Madyan taught in Fez and in Bijāya.

To assess Abū Madyan’s influence and its geographical extent, we have to follow the activities and journeys of his disciples, a lengthy project that entails the consultation of various sources, most of which are listed in the bibliography, below. The list of companions and disciples provided by Ibn Qunfūdh in the Uns al-faqīr is extensive but is still only partial. Al-Tamīmī informs us of the group of friends and disciples that held meetings in Fez with Abū Madyan. Among them were the Andalusian Aḥmad al-Khashshāb and fellow disciples of Ibn Ḥirzihim, such as Muḥammad al-Tāwudī, who originated his own path, leading to al-Sāḥilī (d. 754/1353), and Aḥmad al-Burnusī, with whom Abū Madyan went into retreat on a mountain (Jabal al-Ẓill or Jabal Zālagh), near Fez. Other disciples were Muḥammad b. ʿAlī l-Saqaṭī, reciter of the Qurʾān, and Muḥammad al-Balansī, another Andalusian (al-Tamīmī, 48–50, no. 6; 137–8, no. 55; 94–5, no. 31; 129–31, no. 46; on al-Burnusī, see Ibn ʿAyshūn al-Sharrāṭ, 312–6). Elsewhere in Morocco, Abū Madyan was linked to Abū l-Ṣabr Ayyūb from Sabta (Ceuta), master of al-ʿAzafī (Ferhat, Soufisme , 21). In the Rīf, he had Abū Dāwud Muzāḥim as a disciple (Ferhat, Maghreb , 72; al-Bādisī, 51–2). Moroccans such as Mūsā b. Yadrāsen al-Ḥallāj followed Abū Madyan to Bijāya and surely returned to their homeland after his death (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 330–1). This is certainly also the case with Muḥammad b. Ibrāhīm al-Anṣārī, al-Tādilī’s main informant concerning Abū Madyan (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 320; Ibn Qunfūdh, Uns al-faqīr , 37). We have seen the role played by the Andalusian Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Mariyī, known also as al-Qanjarāy. This person is connected to Abū Muḥammad Sāliḥ (d. 631/1234), the main disciple of Abū Madyan in the western Maghrib, who was taught by ʿAbd al-Razzāq al-Jazūlī (d. 595/1199), another disciple of Abū Madyan (see below), in Alexandria. After his journey in the East, Abū Muḥammad Ṣāliḥ established a ribāṭ (a Ṣūfī monastery) in Asfī (Safi) on the Atlantic coast and organised the Ṭāʾifat al-Ḥujjāj (“The order of the pilgrims”), a brotherhood responsible for organising the pilgrimage (Aḥmad al-Mājirī; Rais, Aspects ; Ferhat, Soufisme , 113–24; Cornell, Realm , 158–61). This master, who studied and resided in Alexandria, plays a major role in the transmission of the teachings and the path of Abū Madyan, in both the Maghrib and the East. One of his disciples, Muḥammad b. Abī l-Qāsim al-Sijilmāsī, initiated al-Ghubrīnī into the path that goes back to Abū Yaʿzā (al-Ghubrīnī, 123–4, no. 25). Ibn Qunfūdh mentions the names of the disciples of Abū Madyan that came from the central Maghrib (from Constantine, Bijāya, and Qalʿat Banī Ḥammād; Ibn Qunfūdh, Uns al-faqīr , 44, 53, 92, 101). His great-grandfather had for a master a disciple of Abū Madyan from Chlef (Ibn Qunfūdh, Uns al-faqīr , 40). Bilāl, the servant of Abū Madyan who remained in al-ʿUbbād after the death of his master, had for a disciple Aḥmad Ibn Marzūq, ancestor of a line of scholars and custodians of the shrine of Abū Madyan (Ibn Qunfūdh, Uns al-faqīr , 93). ʿAbd al-Raḥmān b. Abī Bakr al-Maqqarī (d. 759/1357), another disciple in Tlemcen, also stood at the beginnings of a great family of ʿulamāʾ (cf. Ibn al-Khaṭīb, al-Iḥāṭa , 2:191–2; al-Maqqarī, 5:203–4 ff.).

In Andalusia, the most important disciple of Abū Madyan was Abū Aḥmad Jaʿfar Ibn Sīd Bono (or Būna), whose name refers to the city of Bône, and who died at an old age, in 624/1227. Originating from Cocentaina, in the Denia region of eastern Spain, he travelled east and followed Abū Madyan’s teaching in Bijāya. Upon his return to his homeland, he led many disciples, among whom were Ibn ʿArabī and Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Ḥarrār (d. 615/1218), who settled in Egypt. The Shihāb , which has been attributed to him, is an account of the words that Abū Madyan spoke to him in a dream. After the reconquista of the region of Denia, in 645/1247, the physical and spiritual successors of Abū Aḥmad Jaʿfar settled in the Rabaḍ al-Bayyāzīn (Albaicín, a suburb of Granada) (Ibn al-Abbār, 282, no. 643; Ibn al-Khaṭīb, al-Iḥaṭa , 1:461–3; Massignon, Passion , 2:342–3; Ṣafī al-Dīn, 2b–5b on 213; Sanchez; for other references, see the latter’s n. 5). We know most of the other disciples of Abū Madyan, both native Andalusians and settlers in Andalusia, thanks to Ibn ʿArabī. The second master of the latter, Yūsuf b. Yakhlaf al-Kūmī, introduced him to the Risāla of al-Qushayrī and inculcated in him the veneration of Abū Madyan (Ibn ʿArabī, Rūḥ al-Quds , 79–82, no. 2). ʿAbdallāh al-Mawrūrī (usually spelt incorrectly as al-Marwazī) from Morón de la Frontera, who served Abū Madyan for a long time, related several sayings and anecdotes to Ibn ʿArabī. The latter also recounted the oneiric teachings of Abū Madyan in his Muḥāḍarat al-abrār (Ibn ʿArabī, Rūḥ al-Quds , 99–105, no. 14). Ibn ʿArabī also mentions Abū Aḥmad al-Salāwī, whom he met in Seville, and a certain Abū Marwān ( Rūḥ al-Quds , 100, esp. 118–8, no. 24).

Abū Madyan’s influence extended to the eastern Maghrib, including Bijāya. His main disciples included ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz al-Mahdawī, from Mahdiyya, and settled on the coast, near Tunis (he was buried in La Marsa). Ibn ʿArabī sojourned with him on two occasions and dedicated to him the Futūḥāt al-makkiyya (“The Meccan openings”) and the Rūḥ al-Quds (“Holy Spirit”). Yūsuf al-Dahmānī (d. 621/1224) disseminated the teachings of Abū Madyan in the region of al-Qayrawān, and Abū ʿAlī l-Nafṭī (d. 610/1213) did so in southern Tunisia (on the dissemination of the path of Abū Madyan in Ifrīqiya, see al-ʿĀmirī, al-Taṣawwuf , 103–88).

From Bijāya, Abū Madyan sent his disciple ʿAbd al-Razzāq al-Jazūlī to Alexandria, where he established a ribāṭ , which was to be a point of departure for the spread of his influence along the Nile valley, specifically in Qena, where ʿAbd al-Raḥīm al-Qināʿī (originally from Sabta, d. 592/1196) in turn established a ribāṭ , the influence of which extended into Middle and Upper Egypt. Abu l-Ḥajjāj al-Aqṣurī (d. 642/1244) from Luxor, disciple of ʿAbd al-Razzāq, of ʿAbd al-Raḥīm, and of Abū l-Ḥasan Ibn al-Sabbāgh (d. 612/1215), successor of ʿAbd al-Raḥīm, were the agents of the dissemination of this spiritual path in Egypt. In al-Fusṭāṭ (Miṣr)—specifically, in Qarāfa—two disciples of Abū Aḥmad Jaʿfar Ibn Sīd Būna, Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Ḥarrār (or al-Ḥarīrī) (d. 615/1218), the master of Ṣafī al-Dīn Ibn Abī l-Manṣūr, and Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Ḍarīr (or al-Baṣīr) (d. 623/1226) both established zāwiya s. Abū Muḥammad Ṣāliḥ who resided for a time in Alexandria, left some disciples in the Holy Cities, such as Abū Lakūṭ or Rakūṭ al-Dukkālī (d. 629/1232). The pilgrimage route in the West that goes through Alexandria, the Nile valley, and Upper Egypt facilitated the dissemination of Abū Madyan’s spiritual influence. This is less obvious in the Bilād al-Shām, but one disciple of Abū Yūsuf al-Dahmānī, called Sitt al-Mulūk, settled in Jerusalem (on the path of Abū Madyan in the East, see the Risāla of Ṣafī al-Dīn, Introd., 27–8; Rais, Taʾthīr; and Éric Geoffroy, Rayonnement spirituel et initiatique de Sidi Abû Madyan au Proche Orient (Égypte-Syrie), in Hikmet, 17–37).

How was it that the spiritual path of Abū Madyan survived? In his treatise on initiatory transmission, the Egyptian scholar and Ṣūfī Quṭb al-Dīn al-Qasṭallānī (d. 686/1287) still writes of ṣuḥba with regard to the shaykh s who were connected to the path of Abū Madyan and whom he had known in Mecca in his youth (cf. Irtifāʿ al-rutba , 89–90). A little later, al-Ghubrīnī claimed to have received the path of Ṣūfism (ṭarīq al-taṣawwuf) from his master, from Abū Muḥammad Ṣāliḥ, from Abū Madyan, from Abū Yaʿzā (al-Ghubrīnī, 123–4). Ibn Qunfūdh had received from one of Ibn Marzūq’s family a khirqa that goes back to Bilāl, the servant of Abū Madyan and from him to Ibn Ḥirzihim, Abū Bakr Ibn al-ʿArabī (d. 543/1148), al-Ghazālī, al-Juwaynī (d. 478/1085), Abū Ṭālib al-Makkī (d. 286/996), and al-Junayd, among others. It thus has more the character of the transmission of a science, even though it takes the form of an initiatory transmission. The Yemeni Abū Bakr al-Raddād (d. 821/1418) received from his master Ismāʿīl al-Jabartī (d. 806/1403–4) several khirqa s, one of which goes back to Abū Madyan through Abū Aḥmad Jaʿfar (Gril, 64–8). This suggests that, in the East, the path of Abū Madyan became more the transmission of a spiritual influence than a specific path (ṭarīqa) , although this was perhaps not the case in the West during the eighth/fourteenth century and later. In fact, the Moroccan ʿAlī b. Maymūn al-Fāsī (d. 917/1511) introduced into Syria the Ifrīqī path of Abū Madyan, transmitted by his master Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Tibbasī and the latter’s master Aḥmad b. Makhlūf al-Shābbī (d. 887/1482), both from Ifrīqiya (Geoffroy, Soufisme , 218–22). Contrary to what has been written, the Shādhiliyya did not replace the path of Abū Madyan but existed in other places before it underwent a diversified expansion well into modern times. There have been attempts to turn the master of the Shādhilī, the Moroccan ʿAbd al-Salām Ibn Mashīsh (d. 622/1227) or his master, ʿAbd al-Raḥmān Ibn al-Zayyāt al-Madanī, into a disciple of Abū Madyan (see Ibn ʿAyshūn al-Sharrāṭ, 81), but this remains to be proven (Zouanat, 30–2). This relationship between Abū Madyan and al-Shādhilī is really a matter of the transfer of spiritual function in the hierarchy of sainthood and pre-eminence, expressed in the vision of Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Mursī (d. 686/1287). The latter questions Abū Madyan on his sciences and his spiritual rank and then on those of Abū l-Ḥasan al-Shādhilī. Abū Madyan replies, “He surpasses me (by) forty sciences; it is a sea that one cannot encompass” (Ibn ʿAṭāʾ Allāh, Laṭāʾif , 48). It is signficant that most biographies of Abū Madyan quote only the first part of the vision, in which Abū Madyan mentions his sciences and function, and not the second, in which he mentions Shādhilī’s superiority over him. This vision demonstrates the role that Abū Madyan has played in the history of spirituality in the Muslim West. Those who succeeded him had to position themselves in relation to him. While Abū l-ʿAbbās al-Mursī asserts a continuity, Ibn Sabʿīn (d. 668–9/1269–71), provocatively claims a breach, when he says to his future disciple, the Andalusian Ṣūfī poet al-Shushtarī (d. 667/1269), “If you seek Paradise, go and find Abū Madyan; if you seek the Lord of Paradise, come to me” (al-Maqqarī, 2:185).
4. Architectural traces

The city of Fez has preserved a subtle souvenir of Abū Madyan’s visit: a small mosque bearing his name in the quarter of Rmila, where, according to local tradition, he taught and instructed his disciples (al-Kattānī, 1:415, no. 380; Bel). Immediately after his death, his tomb in al-ʿUbbād began to be visited as a holy place. In 740/1339–40 the Marīnid sultan Abū l-Ḥasan (r. 731–49/1331–48) built a beautiful mosque next to the shrine (Ibn Marzūq, 145, 163–4, 287–8). The architectural complex also includes a madrasa built in 748/1347, where Ibn Khaldūn taught (Marçais and Marçais, 222–82; see the splendid photographs in Khenchelaoui). In Palestine, a waqf (charitable endowment) comprising the al-Aqṣā Mosque is attributed to Abū Madyan. It was founded in 720/1320 by a certain Abū Madyan Shuʿayb b. Muḥammad b. Abī Madyan Shuʿayb al-Maghribī al-ʿUthmānī al-Mālikī, whom Massignon (Documents, 190 ff.) considers a grandson of Abū Madyan. The presence of this waqf has fed the recent legend that Abū Madyan participated in the battle of Ḥaṭṭīn against the Crusaders (583/1187).
5. Descendants

With a black slave, Abū Madyan had a child who died young (Ibn al-Zayyāt, 328). Several Egyptian sources attribute descendants to him. According to Ibn Ḥajar al-ʿAsqalānī (d. 852/1449) (2:290), quoted by the scholar and biographer Aḥmad Bābā of Timbuktu (d. 1036/1627), a great-grandson of Abū Madyan went to Egypt in 757/1356 and died in Ḥamā, in Syria, in 775/1373–4 (Bābā, 199, no. 205). According to al-Shaʿrānī, Abū Madyan’s son Madyan, whose name does not appear in earlier sources, is buried in Cairo, in the mosque of ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Dashṭūṭī (d. 924/1518), a saint from the end of the Mamlūk era (al-Shaʿrānī, 2:133). The kunya Abū Madyan (lit., father of Madyan) does not, however, mean that he actually had a son named Madyan but derives from the fact that Shuʿayb was the prophet sent by God to the people of Midian (Ar. Madyan; Qurʾān 7:85). According to al-Munāwī (3:268, no. 731), Shaykh Madyan al-Ashmūnī (d. 861/1457), whose grandfather came from the Maghrib, was descended from Abū Madyan (a point that al-Shaʿrānī, 2:92, does not clarify). Finally, Aḥmad b. ʿUqba al-Ḥaḍramī (from Ḥaḍramawt, in Yemen, d. 895/1490) replies to his disciple Aḥmad Zarrūq (from Fez, d. 899/1494), who questions him about his path: “I know nothing about that, but my mother is connected (tattaṣilu) to Shaykh Abū Madyan.” Is this a physical or a spiritual relation, or both? (Aḥmad Zarrūq, 42). In present-day Egypt, there is a family that claims to be descended from Abū Madyan. His son Madyan allegedly went to Egypt, had a daughter Fāṭima, the mother of Aḥmad al-Badawī (d. 675/1276), and a son Ṭalḥa, who died in 631/1234 and who allegedly gave his name to the town of Kafr al-Shaykh Ṭalḥa. Although all this is problematic, it belongs to the memory of Abū Madyan, which transcends the confines of history. This is also the case with certain legends, such as the miraculous conversion of Christian monks in Andalusia, to which Abū Madyan never returned (Shuʿayb al-Ḥurayfish, 127). Abū Madyan remains, well into our time, the great saint of the Muslim West.
